childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1988-2000

The smell of fresh Play-Doh. The satisfying click of a Fisher-Price tape recorder. The weight of a Game Boy in your hands, squinting at that unlit screen. Your childhood had a texture that kids today will never know—everything was physical, tangible, present.

At five, you were watching Barney, Lamb Chop's Play-Along, and Sesame Street when it still had a gritty urban edge. By seven, you'd graduated to Rugrats, Doug, and Hey Arnold—shows that treated kids like they had actual inner lives. You probably had strong opinions about whether Tommy or Chuckie was braver. (It was Tommy. Obviously.)

Your school supplies were a statement. Lisa Frank folders with dolphins and rainbows. Trapper Keepers with that satisfying velcro rip. Gel pens in every color for passing notes that would get confiscated. The pencil box with the built-in sharpener that never actually worked.

Friday nights meant one thing: Blockbuster. Walking those aisles, running your fingers across VHS spines, negotiating with siblings over what to rent. The distinct smell of that store—plastic cases and carpet cleaner. The crushing disappointment when someone else had already taken your movie. The backup plan that sometimes turned out better than the original choice.

You ate Dunkaroos, Gushers, and Lunchables. You drank Surge and Hi-C Ecto Cooler (the green Ghostbusters one). You begged for Giga Pets and Tamagotchis, then watched them die from neglect during school hours. You collected Pogs without fully understanding the game. You had a Skip-It and genuinely believed the counter would somehow matter.

At nine, Princess Diana died, and you watched adults cry over someone they'd never met. You didn't understand it then—the parasocial grief, the collective mourning, the way strangers could feel like family through a screen. You understand it now.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

Millennial. The word became an insult before you hit thirty—shorthand for entitled, lazy, avocado-obsessed. Never mind that you're the most educated generation in American history. Never mind that you entered the workforce during the worst economy since the Great Depression. The narrative was set: you killed everything from Applebee's to the diamond industry, apparently by being too poor to afford them.

You were thirteen on September 11, 2001. Eighth grade. You watched the second plane hit live, probably on a TV wheeled into your classroom. Your teachers didn't know what to say. Nobody did. The before and after of that day split your childhood in two. Before: optimism, the end of history, peace dividends. After: orange terror alerts, shoe removal at airports, forever wars in places you'd learn to find on a map.

Your generation spans 1981 to 1996—roughly 72 million Americans. You're the largest living generation, though Gen Z is catching up. You grew up being told you were special, that you could be anything, that the world was yours. Then you graduated into a crater.

The 2008 financial crisis hit when you were twenty. Entry-level jobs evaporated. Internships went unpaid. 'Just get experience' became the mantra, as if experience paid rent. You watched your parents' retirement accounts collapse. You learned, viscerally, that the system could fail—that it would fail, and that nobody would save you when it did.

You're sandwiched between Gen X (who bought houses before they cost half a million dollars) and Gen Z (who never expected to buy houses at all). You still believe things could get better. You're not sure why.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Die Hard came out the year you were born—Bruce Willis in that white tank top, crawling through air ducts, becoming the template for every action movie that followed. Rain Man won Best Picture. Tom Hanks wished himself big. These weren't your movies, but they were in the air, replayed on cable throughout your childhood until you absorbed them through cultural osmosis.

Your actual pop culture education started with Nickelodeon's golden age. You were six when Rugrats premiered, seven for Doug and Ren & Stimpy, eight for Rocko's Modern Life. These shows had an edge—adult jokes hidden in kid-friendly packaging, existential dread dressed up in bright colors. You understood more than the writers expected.

At ten, Toy Story taught you that your toys had feelings, which was either magical or deeply disturbing depending on how you thought about it. At twelve, Titanic had every girl in your class obsessed with Leonardo DiCaprio. You saw it in theaters at least twice. You knew all the words to 'My Heart Will Go On.' (You still do.)

Middle school was TRL and the boy band wars. Backstreet Boys or *NSYNC—you had to choose. Britney vs. Christina. 'MMMBop' stuck in your head for months. You learned all the moves to 'Bye Bye Bye' even if you'd never admit it now. The Macarena at every school dance. 'Who Let the Dogs Out' on repeat.

High school shifted to emo and pop-punk. Dashboard Confessional made sadness feel sophisticated. Fall Out Boy song titles were longer than the songs themselves. My Chemical Romance made eyeliner acceptable for boys. Your MySpace profile had an auto-playing song—probably something by Taking Back Sunday or The Used. You spent hours on your Top 8, knowing the rankings would cause drama.

Then The O.C. premiered when you were fifteen, and suddenly everyone wanted to live in Orange County, listen to indie rock, and have complicated feelings about pool houses. Seth Cohen became a personality template for a generation of nerdy boys. 'California' by Phantom Planet was everywhere.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The sound of dial-up internet is burned into your memory. That screech-and-static handshake meant you were about to wait three minutes for a single image to load, line by line, while nobody in the house could use the phone. You were seven when your family probably got their first internet connection. You were ten when you got your first email address—probably something embarrassing on Hotmail or Yahoo that you hope nobody remembers.

At seven, you experienced Windows 95. That startup sound. The maze screensaver. Minesweeper and Solitaire for hours because there wasn't much else to do on a computer yet. The CD-ROM games: Oregon Trail (you always died of dysentery), Where in the World is Carmen Sandiego, Math Blaster if your parents made you.

AIM changed everything. By twelve, you had a screen name you thought was clever, a buddy list organized by social hierarchy, and away messages crafted like poetry. 'brb,' 'lol,' 'ttyl'—you learned to communicate in a language your parents didn't understand. The door-opening sound when your crush came online. The agony of deciding whether to message first.

You were thirteen when Napster launched, and suddenly you had access to every song ever recorded—if you were willing to wait four hours for a download and risk viruses. LimeWire after that. You burned mix CDs with handwritten track listings. You learned to steal music before you were old enough to buy it legally.

At thirteen, the first iPod arrived. At fifteen, Myspace. At sixteen, Facebook opened to high schools, and you were probably one of the first to join—back when it required a .edu email and nobody's parents were on it. At nineteen, the iPhone dropped, and everything before it suddenly looked ancient.

You're the last generation to remember life before smartphones, before the internet was in your pocket, before every moment was documented. You know what it's like to be bored—truly bored—with nothing to scroll. You can read a map, use a card catalog, remember phone numbers. These are superpowers now.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were fourteen months old when the Berlin Wall fell. Your parents remember watching it live—crowds with sledgehammers, champagne, tears. For them, it was the end of an existential threat they'd lived under their entire lives. For you, it's a historical fact, something you learned about in school. The Cold War was their defining anxiety. You inherited different fears.

The Gulf War happened when you were two—too young to understand, but old enough that it existed as TV images, green night-vision footage that looked like a video game. War as entertainment. You'd see that aesthetic again.

At six, the Oklahoma City bombing. At seven, TWA Flight 800 and the Olympics bombing in Atlanta. At nine, Princess Diana died, and you watched the funeral with 2.5 billion other people. You were learning, without anyone teaching you explicitly, that the world was more fragile than it appeared.

Columbine happened when you were ten. April 20, 1999. You were in fifth grade. You probably didn't watch it live—you were in school—but you felt the aftermath. The lockdown drills started. The clear backpacks. The constant question adults asked each other in lowered voices: 'Could it happen here?'

September 11, 2001 divided history—and your generation's identity was forged in that moment. (You already know where you were.) What came after reshaped the world you'd inherit: Afghanistan, Iraq, the Patriot Act, TSA, the surveillance state. Two decades of war that your generation would fight, and that most Americans would forget was happening.

At twenty, the financial system collapsed. You were in college, or just out, watching the job market evaporate. At twenty-five, gay marriage became legal nationwide—progress you'd never expected to see so fast. At twenty-eight, Trump won, and nothing made sense anymore. At thirty-one, a pandemic shut down the world. You've lived through more 'unprecedented' events than most generations see in a lifetime. You're numb to the word now.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Let's talk about what happened to you. Not what you did wrong—what was done to you.

You graduated college around 2010, give or take. The worst job market since the Great Depression. Entry-level positions required three to five years of experience. Unpaid internships were presented as opportunities. 'Just get your foot in the door' was advice that assumed doors existed.

Your parents' career path looked like this: graduate, get hired, work forty years, get a pension, retire. Your path: graduate, apply to hundreds of jobs, take unpaid internship, take underpaid 'entry-level' job requiring a master's degree, job-hop every two years because that's the only way to get a raise, no pension, no retirement, no security.

The gig economy wasn't invented for you—it was invented to extract value from you. 'Be your own boss' meant no benefits, no stability, no protection. 'Passion' became code for 'we won't pay you fairly.' You were told to love what you do so much that you'd do it for free. Many of you did, because there was no alternative.

You've worked in offices with exposed brick and ping-pong tables, where 'unlimited vacation' meant zero vacation because taking time off was career suicide. You've sat through mandatory fun and culture surveys and all-hands meetings about values while the C-suite gave themselves bonuses and laid off your department.

The cruelest trick was making you believe it was your fault. Not networked enough. Not hustled enough. Not 'leaned in' enough. The truth is the game was rigged before you sat down to play. Wages decoupled from productivity in 1973. The social contract between employers and employees was shredded decades before you entered the workforce. You just got handed the bill.

COVID proved you could work from anywhere, which means now you're expected to work from everywhere, all the time, Slack pinging at midnight. The office is in your pocket. The boundary between work and life isn't blurred—it's gone.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember when having a crush meant learning their class schedule so you could 'accidentally' walk past them? When getting their phone number was a victory, even though calling meant talking to their parents first? When passing a note in class felt dangerously intimate?

You learned to flirt through AIM away messages. Song lyrics meant something. 'brb' when you weren't actually leaving—just waiting to see if they'd say something first. The heartbreak of seeing them go idle. The hope when their buddy icon bounced back to life.

Tinder launched when you were twenty-four. By then, you'd already had relationships the old-fashioned way—meeting at parties, through friends, in college classes. The app changed everything. Suddenly, courtship was a sorting algorithm. Swipe right, swipe left, reduce people to a few photos and a bio. You adapted, because that's what you do, but something was lost.

You're the bridge generation in dating. You remember when meeting someone online was embarrassing, something you'd lie about. ('We met through friends.') Now it's the default. Your Gen Z cousins have never known anything else. Your parents still don't quite understand how it works.

You've delayed marriage, not because you don't want partnerships, but because weddings cost $30,000 and your priorities shifted. You've rejected the timeline your parents followed—married by 25, house by 28, kids by 30—and built something different. Longer courtships. More deliberate choices. Partners who are genuine equals because you've both been through the same fire. You're not immature. You're intentional.

Your friendships span time zones. You've moved for work, for school, for cheaper rent. You maintain relationships through group chats that have been active for a decade, where nobody needs to explain the context because you all lived it. You know how to be close to people who are far away. You've had to learn.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Three economic collapses before you turned thirty-five. The dot-com bust when you were thirteen. The 2008 financial crisis when you were twenty. COVID when you were thirty-one. Each one taught you the same lesson: the floor can fall out at any moment, and nobody's coming to catch you.

Your grandparents saved because they remembered the Depression. Your parents spent because they trusted abundance. You save because you've seen both fail. Your relationship with money isn't rational—it's trauma response.

The numbers tell your story. A median home now costs six times the median income. You got 401(k)s instead of pensions and the advice to 'just invest in index funds' while rent takes 40% of your paycheck. The math is brutally simple: your parents' generation could buy a house on a middle-class salary. You cannot. Full stop.

You graduated with an average of $30,000 in student debt—for a degree you were told was mandatory for the middle class. The interest compounds while you make minimum payments because there's nothing left after rent, utilities, health insurance, car payment, groceries. You'll be paying this debt into your forties. Maybe fifties.

The avocado toast discourse wasn't just insulting—it was gaslighting. The idea that your financial struggles are caused by $8 breakfast items, not by structural economic shifts that happened before you were born. Wages stopped tracking productivity in 1973. You were born into an economy already rigged against workers. The avocado is a scapegoat.

You've redefined success by necessity. Homeownership isn't the goal—it's a fantasy. Retirement at 65 isn't the plan—it's a hope. You're not building wealth to pass down; you're trying not to become a burden to your kids, if you can afford to have them. Financial security means something different when the system is designed to extract from you rather than build with you.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

You're so good at adapting that you've forgotten adaptation isn't the goal. You've optimized your resume, your LinkedIn, your morning routine, your sleep schedule, your macros. You treat systemic problems as personal productivity challenges. The housing crisis isn't a policy failure—it's a budgeting problem you can spreadsheet your way out of. Except you can't.

Your coping mechanisms have become invisible to you. You call it self-care when it's actually survival. You call it hustle culture when it's actually exploitation you've accepted. You've normalized things that should be outrageous: healthcare tied to employment, education requiring debt, retirement as a fantasy. The water you swim in is toxic, and you've stopped noticing the taste.

Irony is your native language, and it's limiting you. You can't just like something—you have to like it ironically, or critique it while consuming it, or distance yourself with humor. Earnestness feels dangerous. Advocacy feels cringe. You hedge everything with self-deprecation because sincerity makes you vulnerable. This makes it hard to fight for what you actually want.

You're conflict-averse in ways that cost you. You've been trained to be team players, to bring solutions not problems, to not rock the boat. You'll accept 'that's just how it is' as an explanation. You'll endure toxic workplaces because the job market is brutal and you need health insurance. You've mistaken accommodation for maturity.

The digital world feels like action, but it's often just performance. You can mobilize for causes on Twitter, but voter turnout in local elections—where policy actually changes—lags far behind engagement metrics. You can cancel celebrities, but changing zoning laws requires showing up to boring city council meetings. The dopamine hit of righteous posting isn't the same as power.

And maybe the deepest blind spot: you've become so good at adapting that you've forgotten adaptation shouldn't be the default mode of existence. You've optimized yourself into exhaustion. The question isn't how to cope better with dysfunction—it's whether you have the clarity to recognize it as dysfunction in the first place. Self-awareness is the first step. What you do with it is up to you.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2008-2018): The decade that forged your resilience. You graduated into the Great Recession, took jobs you were overqualified for, moved back home or crammed into apartments with four roommates. You watched friends who'd done everything right—good grades, good degree, good internships—bartending and driving Uber. The old life script wasn't available. You wrote a new one. The skills you built surviving this decade—adaptability, resourcefulness, low expectations—they'll serve you for life.

Your 30s (2018-2028): You're here now, probably reading this somewhere in the middle of this decade. You're making more money than you did at 25, but it doesn't feel like more. Rent went up. Groceries went up. The goalposts moved while you were running. You're watching Gen Z enter the workforce with TikTok side hustles and no expectation of stability, and you're not sure if they're smarter than you were or more broken. You're supposed to 'settle down,' but settled feels like a trap. You're building something—you're just not sure what.

Your 40s (2028-2038): Statistically, this will be your peak earning decade. You'll have authority at work, clarity about what you want, maybe some acceptance of what you can't change. If you have kids, they'll be getting older, needing less of your physical presence and more of your wisdom (such as it is). Your parents will be aging, needing more. You'll be sandwiched—managing up and down, responsible for generations on either side. Some of you will double down on the life you've built. Some of you will blow it up and start over. Both choices are valid.

Your 50s (2038-2048): You'll be pre-retirement age with no expectation of retiring. You'll have lived through at least four economic crises, probably two pandemics, and so many 'once in a generation' events that the phrase has lost meaning. You'll mentor younger people who can't imagine a world before smartphones, and you'll catch yourself saying things like 'you don't understand' and hating how you sound. You'll be annoyed at their naivety and jealous of it in equal measure.

Your 60s and beyond (2048+): Retirement, if it exists for you, won't look like your grandparents' version—the pension, the gold watch, the decades of leisure. It'll be part-time work, gig economy hustle, reliance on systems that may or may not still exist. Climate change will have reshaped where people can live. The world will be unrecognizable. And you'll tell younger people what it was like before the internet, before smartphones, before everything was connected. You'll tell them about Blockbuster Friday nights and dial-up modems and calling your friends' houses. They won't believe you. It'll sound like science fiction in reverse.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

3.9 million people were born in the US the same year as you. You're part of the 72 million Americans classified as Millennials—the largest living generation, at least for now. Gen Z is catching up.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): You got the same degrees, but they got jobs that paid enough to live on. They bought houses in their twenties. You're still renting in your thirties. They had pensions; you have 401(k)s and the vague hope that Social Security won't collapse before you're seventy. They came of age in economic expansion; you came of age in economic crater. The difference isn't work ethic—it's timing.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is almost comical. When Boomers were your age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. You control 7%. They bought their forever home at 28 on a single income; you're in your thirties with two incomes and still renting. Their houses appreciated 400% while they slept. They lecture you about fiscal responsibility from equity they didn't earn.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You remember the before times. They don't. You still believe, somewhere deep down, that the system can be reformed. They know it's broken and are building around it. You adapted to smartphones as teenagers; they were born with iPads in their hands. You have nostalgia; they have nihilism. Neither of you has savings.

Your life expectancy is 78-80 years—slightly lower than previous generations, thanks to rising 'deaths of despair' (suicide, overdose, alcoholism). Your generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before, which is treated as a personal failing rather than a rational response to irrational conditions.

But you've also made the world genuinely better. You normalized therapy. You destigmatized mental health struggles. You pushed for marriage equality and racial justice and trans rights in ways your parents' generation refused to. You inherited a harder world and made it more inclusive. The economy is rigged against you, but the culture shifted because you showed up. That matters.

year_events: George H.W. Bush won the presidency
Die Hard invented the modern action movie
